Robert Gordon Menzies, react to the news that the Auburn North branch of the very same party had refused admission to a prospective member on the basis of to whom she is married? Surely he would not be pleased. Ms Ann Peacock was the unsuspecting victim of a most un-Liberal act. The daughter of a former Liberal foreign minister, her only crime is to have walked down the aisle with Michael Kroger.

For those who might see this act as part of the wider war within the Victorian branch of the Liberal Partyâbetween the forces of Mr Kroger and his nemesis, the Premier of Victoriaâthe news is: you are wrong. All the people involved in the refusal to accept Ms Peacock's membership have been completely disowned by the Premier of Victoria. Indeed, the dust was flying in the rush by prominent Liberals to disown the actions of this renegade branch. The Premier swooped to Ms Peacock's aid, as did the Prime Minister, as did Mr Kroger's candidate for the leader of the Liberal Party: the Treasurer.

The member for Kooyong intervened in the affairs of the local branch and ensured Ms Peacock's membership was accepted, against the wishes of his local upper house member, David Davis. Even Ms Peacock's mother, Lady Renouf, threatened to withdraw her extensive involvement in Liberal Party fundraising. This is but one incident in the tensions seething below the surface of the Liberal Party. It appears that this may be merely the latest example of the continuing dispute between Messrs Kennett and Krogerâthe Brutus and Mark Antony of modern conservative politics.

The next great flashpoint for the continuing wars between these two will undoubtedly be the carving up of preselections for that state's election, which is due later this year. There has already been a delay in the processes. One thing that is guaranteed is that there will be a number of very hotly contested contests later on. The state seat of Bulleen promises to be one of the nastiest contests. The local member, David Perrinâa bete noire of the Premier'sâwill be facing a challenge from Nick Kotsiras, an adviser to the Premier. In Doncaster, there may be a challenge to Victor Perton. Mr Perton is in the invidious position of being disliked by both the Kennett and Kroger forces, so it would appear his only chance of survival would be a strong performance in his local plebiscite.

But the battle for Bulleen may be of wider moment. The most interesting aspect of the fight is not who might win but whether there is a larger agenda involved. The Premier of Victoria likes a good purge, so in some circles the fact that he might be supporting Mr Kotsiras for Bulleen comes as no surprise. It might also be the case, however, that the Premier has a more mid-term interest in the preselection than merely who will be the next member for Bulleen. Mr Kotsiras may be paving the way for Mr Kennett's eventual challenge in the seat of Menzies. It is no secret in Victorian political circles that the current member for Menzies, regrettably, is opposed by some sections of his own party. Indeed, it has been suggested the honourable member will find his most trenchant critics among the ranks of state Liberals. These people whisper that Mr Kennett is a more palatable choice for them as their Canberra representative. Indeed, one of the Greek language pamphlets distributed in the Bulleen preselection claimed that the Kotsiras push was organised for this very purpose.

No-one knows whether Kennett will go federal, but his recent interest in everything from the preamble to youth suicide, heroin and One Nation shows some inclination. It will be especially so if his `friend' the Treasurer falters in his bid for Liberal leadership. In an article in the Herald Sun on 8 April, Michael Harvey, the Chief Political Reporter, wrote:

If however, he (Kennett) decided a Canberra career was the next step, the Premier would have little difficulty landing himself a safe Federal seat. Victorian Liberals concede the outer eastern metropolitan electorate of Menzies, held by Liberal Kevin Andrews, is Mr Kennett's for the taking. The margin slipped to 5.5% at the October general election . . .
Perhaps he will be joined by the member for Goldstein, whose mooted early retirement might leave Michael Kroger with a clear run in the resultant preselection.

This leads us fairly naturally to the state of play in the festering ambitions of the two PetesâP1 and P2, as the press gallery's Michelle Grattan calls them. It is interesting to watch from over here their assiduous working of the backbench and other colleagues. Who can forget the memorable announcement by Michael Kroger on Lateline of his friend the Treasurer's candidacy for the top job? According to a fascinating report in the Sunday Herald Sun, events are more advanced than any of us realised. You will forgive me, Mr Speaker, but because the source of my analysis is a Melbourne weekend paper I was not sure that it had been given the attention that it deserves, so I intend to read from it. The article stated:

It is common knowledge that Mr Howard, who turns 60 in July, always wanted to be Prime Minister for the Sydney Olympics, but as the event approaches, some Howard confidantes say Malcolm Fraser's record of seven years and four months and even Bob Hawke's term of eight years and nine months are beckoning.
But Mr Costello will not want to wait that long. In fact, there is growing evidence that his backers believe he should not even wait until after the next Federal Election . . .
Costello supporters are quietly working the backbench suggesting a voluntary changeover is highly probable this term . . .
Gerard McManus added:
The PM's office has learned of a network of key Costello organisers from each state who have been selected to gather support.
One influential Liberal in the Howard camp this week unkindly described some of Mr Costello's supporters as comprising "the desperate, duplicitous and the dispossessed".

The dispossessed is said to include former ministers still scarred from being dumped by Mr HowardâQueensland's David Jull, New South Wales MP Andrew Thomson and WA MP Geoff Prosser and Judi Moylan. The desperate is said to include Dr Brendan Nelson, Christopher Pyne and Petro Georgiou, who, despite their political skills have been frozen out of the Ministry.
Mr Pyne, an influential moderate, has been wooed by Mr Costello and powerbroker Michael Kroger since the last election.

Turning to the ambitions of the member for Flinders, according to some, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business is a ubiquitous guest at Liberal Party backbenchers' birthday partiesâmost recently attending Senator Grant Chapman's celebrations. I cannot believe the stories, however, that the minister is travelling the country cutting the cake and singing `happy birthday'. It is unclear whether he was travelling with or without his prime ministerial baton. Tony Wright, the chief political correspondent for the Age , wrote on 27 February:

. . . Peter Reith is busily reminding everyone he is not only a republican, but tripping off to Sydney right in front of the TV cameras to talk to former independent MP Ted Mack about giving the people of Australia the right to elect their own President. The people's Peter. And just for good measure, he popped up on TV last Sunday, suggesting he was such an optimist that he believed Australia could reduce unemployment below 5 per centâif only his ideas are adopted.

The same day, on another station, Costello was claiming ownership of Reith's leaked ideas on how to reduce unemployment, declaring "Well, what Peter has done, is he's really put some detail on some of the things that I was saying . . . "
Another tantalising explanation for the enthusiasm of the minister for workplace relations for the ultra-republican position appeared in the Australian of 15 February:
There are those inside the government who, in trying to divine Reith's tealeaves, suspect his republican play may have been aimed at currying favour with Howard.

The various activities of P1 and P2 could be an irrelevancy, however. My mail is that the smart money is on a dark horse; a senator evenâthe Gorton option again. The Prime Minister has a favourite, but his name is not Peter; it is Nick. It is Senator Nick Minchin. If the Prime Minister can swing it, he reputedly would much prefer to hand over the reigns to the senator from South Australia.

This may seem mere speculation, perhaps even mischievous speculation, on my part. I reject any such suggestion. Let us not forget some of the immortal quotes from other famous conservative leaders who said they would never challenge for the leadership: `I can assure you of our complete loyalty to John Gorton'âSir William McMahon pledging loyalty to Sir John Gorton in 1969, some months before he toppled him from the job. `The party room has a right to express a view. It has done this, and I respect its decision and I support the parliamentary leader of the Liberal Party'âMalcolm Fraser in November 1974 after losing a challenge to Billy Snedden, four months before he defeated him. `Look, John Howard is the leader, and I would not challenge his leadership'âdeposed Liberal leader Andrew Peacock in September 1985 after losing his job to Mr Howard. In May 1989, Mr Peacock did just that, and won. Finally, `I accept completely that I'll never be the leader of the Liberal Party again. It's out of the question'âJohn Howard in May 1994, eight months before winning the Liberal Party leadership again. It is my strong contention that these matters and particularly the matters raised by Gerard McManus in the SundayHerald Sun about the various factions operating in this House should be of great concern to the Australian people.

talk.start.para: âI want to say a few words in this grievance debate about unemployment in my electorate of Fairfax, and the Sunshine Coast region of Queensland generally. At the outset, I will repeat what I have said many timesâI believe firmly that only the private sector can create and provide long-term sustained job growth in Australia. You can have as many public sector jobs as you like, you can try to hide the level of real unemployment in training schemes, you can use public moneys for public works to either inflate or deflate the economy, but there is no substitute for private sector jobs created through investment and growth and by the willingness of individuals to risk their capital.

speech.para: The Labor government, in 13 years, tried to stimulate job growth through public sector spending. They hid the unemployment in training figures, and in five short years racked up $70 billion worth of public debt. Consequently, the Labor government gave us the recession we had to have, record bankruptcies in the engine of growthâthat is, small businessâand, because the Commonwealth was a major borrower in the market, record high interest rates. Labor left us with an army of unemployed people. This government realises that the private sector, especially the small business sector, is the creator of jobs.

In my electorate on the Sunshine Coast we have always had a higher rate of unemployment than most places. We have some of the fastest growing shires in Australia, with 1,200 to 1,400 people being added to the electoral rolls each month. Many of these new people are retirees or younger people wanting a better lifestyle than they have in the cities. Sadly, and this is by no means unique to the Sunshine Coast, we do tend to attract unemployed people who have no intention of working but who find it more pleasant to be on the dole in Noosa, Maroochydore or Mooloolaba than in Sydney or Melbourne. However, these people are not my main concern. My main concern is for the 6,000 children of school leaving age who reach work force age during the life of each parliament in my electorate. That is at one end of the scale.

At the other end of the scale is my concern for older people who lose their jobs in their 40s and 50s. I grieve for the despair I see on the faces of these older people who feel they are on the scrap heap at a time when they should be at the peak of their working careers. The Howard government is on the only track to generate employment and provide these desperate unemployed people with some hope. Running a strong fiscally responsible government, paying off Labor's debt and taking the pressure off interest rates creates a climate of business confidence the like of which we have not seen for 30 years. Australia is growing and has weathered the Asian economic crisisâand remember that Labor voted against every measure that enabled this government to weather that crisis.

Unfortunately, growth and jobs do not occur uniformly across the nation or even by region. In my electorate, Coolum is such a place. Jobs growth, investment and development have occurred rapidly over three years on the Sunshine Coast at Maroochydore, Mooloolaba, Noosa and other places but not at Coolum. That is where this government's policy of help and assistance to the unemployed is a different approach from Labor's. This government is not getting carried away with the good news that we tend to hear more and more frequently on a daily basis as a consequence of our sound economic management. We know that we needed growth to generate jobs but we also know that jobs growth has not occurred uniformly and that some regions and towns either need help that others do not need or need help more urgently. Because this government is a compassionate government, it is our policy to provide special help where it is needed.

Coolum will benefit from economic growth and jobs that will be created in the long term. In the short term, unemployed people need special assistance because of the lack of public transport and because government and employment services are located in nearby larger centres in Maroochydore, Nambour and Noosa. I applaud my colleague employment minister Tony Abbott, a relatively new minister, who visited Coolum recently and immediately recognised the special problems of the town and approved the installation of an employment touch screen in the local community centre. Coolum is an old town on the Sunshine Coast that tends to have lower accommodation costs than many of the other more glamorous centres in the area. Coolum tends to have a lower household disposable income, higher unemployment and many more social problems than the surrounding areas. The installation of this touch screen was very valuable. This is the first time a touch screen which accesses the Australian jobs market has been installed outside of the Job Network providers. It gives me great satisfaction to see that unemployed people in Coolum now have immediate access to the jobs market enjoyed by other people on the Sunshine Coast.

The Work for the Dole scheme is providing the unemployed with self-esteem and is restoring to many in despair the work ethic. The special access to job vacancies gives these people hope and a chance of jobs that they have not had for a long time. The Work for the Dole program is helping long-term unemployed people gain skills and experience while they help with local community projects. These are all good initiatives that this government has introduced and they are supported by most Australians. But the chal lenge now is to ensure that people living in regional areas like my electorate of Fairfax do not miss out on jobs because of geography. I want to again thank the Minister for Employment Services, the Hon. Tony Abbott, for recognising the particular difficulty we have had in my electorate and for doing something very positive about it.

My electorate office is also located at Coolum. As I said before, it is located between Maroochydore and Noosa, where government services like Centrelink and Job Network are located. It is not far from either township or from Nambour. Nambour is about 30 minutes away inlandâthat is if you have a car and can afford to run it. For most unemployed people in the Coolum area, the only option is public transport and in regional areas buses do not run as cheaply or as frequently as they do in the cities. That is just one stumbling block for Coolum people in getting a job. The other, as I said, is accessing a jobs touch screen to see what jobs are available. The director of the community centre, Rod Holt, tells me that the touch screen is a great help and very popular with the local community. Many people from Coolum have now been placed in jobs as a result of Tony Abbott's agreement to put that touch screen in the community centre. However, I must say in conclusion we still need more government services in Coolum.

talk.start.para: âI am very pleased to be speaking today on the need for renewed efforts to reduce smoking in our community. Smoking is the largest preventable cause of death and disease and it generates health and social costs of $12.7 billion annually. Twelve years ago, I was working for the then Minister for Health in Victoria, David White, when he introduced landmark legislation to control tobacco advertising. This legislation establishedâas a world firstâVicHealth, a foundation that redirected tobacco taxes into health promotion activities including the Quit campaign. There has been steady progress since then with reductions in adult smoking rates. However, young people are still taking up smoking in alarming num bers and smoking remains our number one health problem.

speech.para: Smoking still kills more than 18,000 people every year. Almost a third of cancer deaths and a quarter of heart disease are directly attributable to the use of tobacco. Every year more people die from tobacco related diseases than from breast cancer, liver disease, homicide, suicide, AIDS and all accidents combined. Yet there remains an absence of a clear strategy and adequate funding from the government in its attack on this problem. There has been a loss of momentum in the last few years and the resources being put into tobacco control have failed to keep pace with the problem.

The Minister for Health and Aged Care put out a statement today that suggested the anti-smoking movement started in 1996. What I would rather do today is give due credit to all those who have been campaigning for so many years in the fight against tobacco related diseases. Included in that I would like to mention the efforts made by the member for Fremantle, who put in place a number of initiatives during her tenure as Minister for Health which are bearing fruit today. One of her initiatives was the establishment of the Rassaby inquiry to find a solution to the vexed problem of the international sponsorship of sportâand we are still waiting for the minister to implement those findings. She also provided $3.1 million in 1994 to enable a substantial national television campaign to be conducted with a principal target of deterring young people from commencing a smoking habit.

The news today that the number of regular smokers has been reduced by 1.4 per cent is indeed encouraging. The recent series of shock advertisements that the government has run has been effective, even if it has been a rather modestly funded campaign. But it is not good enough to run just an isolated campaign or two and then to sit back and admire the results. What we have to have is consistent, on-going effort.

Another important factor in reducing smoking rates has been the rapid spread of nicotine patches, which have been heavily and effectively promoted by the manufacturers of these products. Nicotine replacement therapy, as it is formally known, has become a major weapon in the fight against smoking because it gives a real hand to the addicted, heavy smokers for whom willpower alone is insufficient to stop smoking. By providing an alternative source of nicotine, it becomes possible for heavy smokers who are at most risk of damaging their health to work towards their goal of completely stopping. At present nicotine patches are very expensive and beyond the reach of some of the most addicted smokersâworking people on middle to low incomes.

For every one of these people who give up smoking, the communityâand the individualâstands to gain handsomely in reduced health costs in future years. And, remarkably, this effect is not limited by age. For example, a person of 50 who has smoked all of his or her adult life will still benefit, by giving up smoking, through improved health in the remaining years of life and a longer life expectancy. It is never too late for us to quit. Hence there are great advantages for the community as a whole in promoting anti-smoking campaigns and in maximising participation in nicotine replacement strategies for those who find it very hard to give up. In the UK Tony Blair's Labour government has introduced radical new measures to provide nicotine patches free for the first 30 days as a central plank of a new national strategy on smoking cessation.

I sincerely hope that the minister will take up this suggestion and incorporate a subsidised approach to ensure the success of nicotine replacement therapy and to make sure it is available to everybody in the community. But getting people to quit is not good enough if we continue to have 70,000 young people a year take up smoking. A child who starts smoking at 14 is five times more likely to die prematurely than a person who starts at 24 or older. Surveys show more than one-quarter of 15-year-old students had smoked in the preceding week. There is a lot more that needs to be done to convince young people not to take up the smoking habit and to help working people overcome their addiction.

I certainly do not doubt the sincerity of the present minister in relation to this issue. As a doctor, he is well aware of the impact of smoking, and he displays the commitment common amongst the medical profession to strong and effective measures to reduce the extent of smoking and the harm that it causes. But if the minister wants a reputation for achievement on tobacco he will have to do more. The Rassaby report recommended a clear strategy to phase out international sponsored events. This seems to have been shelved, and foreshadowed legislation to end this backdoor advertising has failed to materialise.

The only recommendation from the 1997 national cancer control initiative that has been implemented is the change to the method of calculating excise duty. The industry has just been given a $140 million break in this year's budget by a deferral of the effective date for introducing `per stick' excise charges. There has been no action on tougher warnings on cigarette packets and no crackdown on sales to underage smokers. The tobacco industry, in its own documents, has acknowledged that it has manipulated the level of nicotine in cigarettes to ensure that people continue smoking. There is no regulatory mechanism in Australia to track the nicotine content of cigarettes.

The minister set a deadline of last July for tobacco companies to finally disclose the chemical content of cigarettes but has taken no action on the replies that I understand he has received. For too long, Australians have been kept in the dark about the numerous chemical additives that are being put into cigarettes to make them more marketable without regard for the health effects. The minister should start by disclosing whatever information he has. The next step would be for him to introduce legislation to require the contents of cigarettes to be printed on the packet. This is a requirement for all food and most other products that are for personal use. Despite the widespread impact on the community, tobacco remains relatively unregulated.

The federal government collects around $4.5 billion each year in revenue from smok ers, including $64 million from underage smokers. Total expenditure on anti-smoking education in Australia by contrast has declined from 0.77 per cent of total government revenue from tobacco in 1989 to 0.14 per cent in 1997. The amount spent on anti-smoking advertisements is just one-third of the amount spent by this government promoting private health insurance. It is not enough to leave it to the states. There must be strong national leadership and access to federal government funding.

The government is currently consulting on a draft tobacco strategy for the next three years. I urge the government to be bold and to ensure that the campaign against smoking does not falter for lack of funding or willpower on the part of the government. The government needs to look at a comprehensive approach that includes subsidised nicotine treatment, controls on advertising at point of sale, enforceable targets for the tobacco industry to deter underage smoking and either enforcement of the underage sales provisions or further controls on the places where cigarettes may be sold.

The momentum of the anti-smoking campaign will be lost if this minister does not act soon. It is time that we saw a strong strategy for the next three years to put this campaign back into gear. If we do not see that from this government, substantial progress will have to wait until the next election when we can look forward to the Labor government tackling the unfinished business that we left in 1996.

talk.start.para: âI agree with much of what the member for Jagajaga said, but I have to sadly disillusion her on the last pointâshe will be still sitting in opposition after the next election. I rise today to urge the Senate to pass the legislation for the sale of the next 16 per cent of Telstra. I want to outline some of the terrific benefits of the sale of the first 33 per cent. Apart from the significant reduction in government debt, a number of benefits have been passed on to people particularly in regional Australia. It is interesting to note that the Labor Party continues to oppose this, and yet it was the Labor Party that went down the path of privatising the Commonwealth Bank. Before an election, a former Labor Treasurer, Mr Willis, even went so far as to say, `We have no plans of further privatisation,' only to go past the election and take the next step towards privatising part of the Commonwealth Bank.

speech.para: The sale of the first 33 per cent of Telstra erased nearly $15 billion of debt. It is interesting to note that while that sale made many new shareholdersâmany Australians for the first time in their lives became shareholders in Telstraâthe sale of the next 16 per cent will probably raise a similar amount of money because the value of those shares has gone up quite significantly. It would mean that not only have many Australians benefited but also the taxpayers of Australia would receive a direct benefit because we would be paying off government debt and doing a number of other things that would also mean lower interest charges and therefore lower taxes.

It is interesting to note that, as part of this sale of the next 16 per cent, the government is proposing a $671 million social bonus. I understand that the matter is still under some negotiation, but I hope that the Senate will see the sense of this social bonus and the value that it will mean for regional Australia in particular but Australia in general. There would be $250 million more for the Natural Heritage Trust. This very important program was started by the coalition government, and it is one that I believe now has widespread support throughout the community. It has ensured that the environment is now a mainstream policy issue and will remain that way.

It has meant we have had community based projects that have involved tens of thousands of Australians. In the last two rounds in my electorate of Wannon we have seen many local organisations successfulâin fact, more than 100âand more than $2Â½ million in federal funding has come through that program and is being spent very wisely and in a way that I am sure all Australians would be very pleased to hear about. These programs have included restoring vegetation, repairing land that has been eroded, eliminating feral pests and weeds, clearing our rivers and working on our coastal strips. There is no doubt that future generations will gain great benefit from the work that has been done there.

In many areas it has set out to reverse the degradation of our land, our waterways and our coasts. It has also set out to conserve some of our precious biological diversity and to ensure that we can act in a way that does not damage the life support systems on our planetâvery important programs and ones that I think have widespread support. The fund is also helping to clean up our rivers, restore some native vegetation and tackle dryland salinity. Again, I think it is so important that the proposed sale of the next tranche of Telstra goes ahead so that we can continue this excellent work.

The next area that is very important, particularly for people in regional areas, is the extension of SBS and also the work on eliminating television black spots. In my region and in many other parts of regional Australia there are many people who cannot get SBS television, yet it is provided free of charge to people in the city and they take it for granted. One hundred and twenty million dollars will establish a television fund which will be used to expand SBS to all broadcast communities of more than 10,000 people. This, coupled with fixing between 200 and 250 transmission black spots around the country, will mean that more than one million Australians in regional areas will get a service that city dwellers have been taking for granted. It is clear that the high cost of providing the additional transmitters cannot be met locally and, through the sale of Telstra, this is a logical way of using some of the dividend so that it is part of the social bonus.

In September last year I lodged a submission with the economic development committee of the Victorian parliament which was conducting an inquiry into the effects of government funded national broadcasting on Victoria. In calling for community input to the submissions, I received written input from 67 individuals, several petitions and representations from several community groups. There were many submissions following similar lines, but SBS was one of the main areas that came through from those submissions. People felt that the inequality of living in the country and not being able to get that access was just unreasonable and something that the government had to address. In its report that committee has followed through on these points and on a number of others and has recognised the benefits of SBS for people in the country as well as in the city.

Another area that the social bonus will be applied to is the rural transaction centres. This is a policy that the current government developed, and it developed it in direct response to the then Financial Institutions and Public Administration Committee, now the Economics, Finance and Public Administration Committee of which I am honoured to be the chairman. I note another member of the committee is here, the member for Grayndler. He knows that we did some excellent work in looking at the impact in the country of the closure of local bank branches. The committee's work, even though the committee had not reported at the time of the next election, had direct influence on both the coalition and the Labor Party in the development of their policies for regional banking.

The coalition came up with an excellent policy of the rural transaction centres, and over $70 million from the social bonus from the sale of the 16 per cent of Telstra is to be applied to establish a network of rural transaction centres. These are not only to assist in providing banking where that may not be but also to extend postal, Medicare, phone and fax services to smaller country towns. Clearly, by assisting in establishing this infrastructure, the government can apply this money sensibly and in a way that, again, helps people in regional Australia to benefit from getting services that people in larger centres just take for granted.

Another area where this money from the sale of Telstra will be applied is to extend mobile phone coverage. Twenty-five million dollars will be used to provide continuous mobile phone coverage along 11 of the nation's busiest highways, thus eliminating irritating and potentially dangerous black spots of mobile phone coverageâagain, something that people in the city tend to take for granted but something that can be ex tremely frustrating in the country. I can say on behalf of all my country colleagues from both sides of the chamber, as members of parliament I think they all know just how frustrating it is when you are driving around your electorate trying to use the phoneâof course in a hands-free modeâ

talk.start.para: âCome to western Tasmania.

âIf you come to western Victoria it is no different. There is that frustration of not being able to use that telephone when you know that your colleagues in the city just take it for granted. These mobile phone base stations are quite expensiveâthey can cost up to $300,000 eachâand so the phone companies will not always find it economic to extend that coverage. But, by using this social bonus, again we can see tremendous benefits.

speech.para: There is also money for Internet local points of presenceâanother thing that will directly benefit the countryâand more money for the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund, which is already doing some fantastic work in the country areas but clearly is going only part of the way.

I urge the Senate to get on with passing the legislation to sell the next 16 per cent of Telstra. The benefits to the nation and to regional Australia will be very significant. It is clear that by doing this there will be a way of funding these programs which otherwise will not receive funding in the near future. Whether it be for Natural Heritage Trust funding or extending SBS and other television coverage or setting up the rural transaction centre or extending Internet local points of presence or expanding the regional telecommunications infrastructure all are extremely valuable programs. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe opportunity to take part in the grievance debate is always welcomed by members as it gives us the opportunity to raise issues that are of concern in the electorate. My grievance, which came to light last week, seemed to the people who raised it with me to be one that could be easily remedied. The grievance seemed worthy of being addressed quickly. It stemmed from a request for assistance from Metro-Claremont Soccer Club to enable three Kosovo refugees to play competition soccer in Tasmania. One would have thought this was a simple matter easily solved. These refugees were not wanting to play for any of the top soccer clubs in Australia. Anyone who had any interest in soccer would know that the National Soccer League final ended successfully for South Melbourne on Sunday. All these refugees wanted to do was to break up the monotony of life in the refugee camp by playing a sport they love in the local competition for Metro-Claremont. This club, led superbly by Jimmy McKinnon, has done a fantastic job in ensuring that the Kosovo refugees have their own sports gear and can train with Metro-Claremont as regular team members.

speech.para: So I had a problem. My first port of call was to phone the office of Jackie Kelly, the Minister for Sport and Tourism, to seek her assistance. The minister's office handballed it away by suggesting that I call the Australian Sports Commission. They were at least a little bit helpful by giving me a name and a phone number in Soccer Australia. It was obvious that the minister and her office did not see this issue as one that could be used to put out a press release, perhaps get a photo in the national dailies or appear on the network TV channels. Foolish woman; shallow woman. This minister is obviously blinkered. She is interested only in the front row seat she will be sitting in at the Sydney Olympics. She is known out in the electorate as the minister for handing out cheques. It is obvious that she has no understanding of, or interest in, grassroots sports people.

What happened when I spoke to Soccer Australia? Their interest was as shallow and as uncaring as the minister's. After numerous phone calls, they finally got back to me with the news that they had been in contact with FIFA. FIFA's response showed that their concern for their grassroots soccer clubs and players was about as relevant as the IOC's for its athletes. Amazingly, FIFA said that Yugoslavia was operating normally and that the Kosovars did not fit within FIFA's nomadic definition of refugees. FIFA must only watch Foxtel sports channel 24 hours a day. They said that the applications by the Kosovars had to be addressed by the Yugoslav Soccer Federation. If no response was received in 60 days, FIFA said that Soccer Australia could issue the Kosovars with an interim clearance to play in Tasmania. Big deal. Tasmania's soccer season would be finished by then. What a farce.

This smouldering issue suddenly burst into flames nationally and internationally as a consequence of FIFA's response. Jackie Kelly, the minister, suddenly woke up when she realised that this issue was of real concern out in the electorate to heaps of people and that, if she did not become involved, she would lose control of the situation. Too late! Jackie Kelly went into damage control when she announced at a hastily called media conference at Bellerive Oval last Friday that the refugees would be allowed to play in Tasmania after all. They would play as a Kosovo celebrity team. She said:
If they do stay here long enough, I've been assured by Soccer Australia it will take steps to enable them to join clubs of their choice.

My response to this is that by playing as a celebrity team it does not allow any of the refugees to realise their full potential and is a token gesture to take the pressure off the minister and Soccer Australia. They are stateless people, unaware of when they are going to be able to return to their homes, and both the minister and Soccer Australia must act immediately to break through this ridiculous red tape.

There was a wonderful cartoon in the Tasmanian Mercury, which most mainlanders would not have seen, last Friday. A FIFA delegate, identified by his bag, had a question to the three Kosovo refugees: `Have you been cleared?' The response: `Only from our homes!' On the following day there was a wonderful editorial from the Mercury entitled `Breaking the rules'. It read:
Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic and three of his closest allies have just been indicted by the world tribunal which prosecutes war crimes.
They are crimes which focus on the barbarous ethnic cleansing some Serbian troops have con ducted against ethnic Albaniansâand othersâin Kosovo.
As a consequence of this ethnic cleansing, hundreds of thousands of Kosovos have fled their homeland to neighbouring countries to try to stay alive.
Many members of the international community have offered temporary safe haven to thousands of these refugees. Among them is Australia, which has been forthright in its criticism of Milosevic.
At the same time, Yugoslavia is prosecuting two Australian aid workers, alleging that they were spies. Milosevic has refused meetings with Australians acting for the aid workers.
All in all, Milosevic has no reason to feel friendly towards Australia. Going on his history and behaviour, it seems he has very little reason to feel friendly towards anybody.

Imagine then the depth of stupidity required by a soccer officialâliving under such a dictatorâto act independently and in the spirit of sportsmanship and to agree to give a clearance to play to three Kosovos who have sought refuge in Australia. Imagine this official's fear of the consequences.

Imagine also the depth of stupidity required by international soccer officialdom for insisting that such a clearance is necessary if the three refugees are to be allowed to play club soccer in Hobart.
Imagine, even if Milosevic was not a brutal tyrant, trying to contact a sporting body in a country which is in a state of war asking for a clearance for players who are regarded as the enemy.
None of the refugees are household names in soccer. Manchester United is not knocking down their doors at the Brighton Safe Haven camp to grab their signatures.
In fact, according to Hobart's Metro-Claremont soccer team, the players will probably only make the reserve side. Yet they have been prevented by red tape from even doing this.

The intervention yesterday by Federal Sports Minister Jackie Kelly did nothing more than provide Milosevic with a win and soccer officialdom with an attempted face-saver. It did not work. Soccer's face should still be red. As should Ms Kelly's.

After all, she pointed out that should the refugees be in Australia long enough, then the way is clear for the controlling bodies to grant them permits to play. Why can't that be done now? Who determines what constitutes `long enough'.
Tasmanian Labor MHR Harry Quickâwho has been trying to break through the bureaucratic barrierâsummed up the pre-Kelly situation with good Australian succinctness: `It's bloody ridiculous.'
Most people would think that Mr Quick was being unduly generousâMs Kelly's `solution' notwithstanding.

This is an issue that has worldwide attention. I have done a couple of interviews on the BBC World Service. Minister, get out of your seat and talk to Soccer Australia about a real resolution to this issue. To do anything less is a real abrogation of your duty to sportspeople throughout Australia and throughout the world.

talk.start.para: âIn this grievance debate tonight, I would like to make the House aware of the good work being done in Gladstoneâthe engine room of my electorate and, indeed, of Queensland. The week before last, it was my honour to introduce the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, the Hon. Nick Minchin, to the energetic city of Gladstone. I note that the minister at the table, Mr Vaile, is smiling. He has also been on one of these high-powered visits to Gladstone. Mayor Peter Corones was sadder than I was to see Minister Minchin leave. He talked about introducing an adopt-a-minister program, and he was about to adopt Senator Minchin.

speech.para: Jokes aside, 10 per cent of Australia's commodity exports travels through the Port of Gladstone. It is the fastest growing port in Australia. Like many other parts of regional Australia, it stands to gain tremendously from tax reform. Gladstone has its own distinctive character of youth, drive and enthusiasm. It is the envy of many cities. Not only that, but it has the ability to balance the environment with industrial progress, which is a unique mix. It is marked to become an industrial leader in the new millennium.

That statement is not empty rhetoric. Gladstone, the adjoining shire of Calliope and, to a lesser extent, the next shire down the line, Miriam Vale, are hosts to the emerging giants of Australian manufacturingâQueensland Alumina, Boyne Smelters, Orica, Ticor and QCL, to name a few. Each value adds to the products it treats and, in some cases, this is as high as a 10 to one factor. It is an enviable performance by any standard. The importance of Queensland Alumina and Boyne Smelters and the aluminium industry in particular is highlighted by Comalco's proposal to erect a $1.4 billion refinery. Linked with that is the Chevron gas pipeline and still further down the trackâalthough not directly linked with thisâis the satellite launching facility at Hummock Island. That makes the resolution of the Wik debacle all the more relevant.

Senator Minchin, a representative of the state Department of State Development and I went by helicopter to look at the whole profile of Gladstoneâas I did with the minister at the table, but the visit was even more comprehensive on this occasion. We looked at the proposed rocket base, Boyne Smelter, QAL, the port facilities, QCL, the site for Comalco, the oil shale site, Orica, and Ticor. In the space of an hour, the minister had a thumbnail sketch of the whole industrial profile of the area. One of the members from the Hunter Valley region is looking enviously at me and thinking, `Why aren't some of these things happening in Newcastle?' I am sure that Newcastle will return to better daysâand I was there only last week.

I have a particularly soft spot for Gladstone, not only because it is in my electorate but because it is a get-up-and-do townâa very positive community. While we were in Gladstone I took the opportunity of taking the minister to see Premron Engineering. That was an eye-opener. It is a family business which is competing with overseas manufacturers as an alternative source of mining and heavy industrial parts. It is having plenty of success. In the days when the big coalfields went in in central Queensland, a lot of equipment was sourced from overseas. In the boom times of those early resource days, cost was not a problem. But the time has now come to replace some huge gears and things like that which cost hundreds of thousands or even millions of dollars. Premron Engineering has demonstrated that it can do this in Australia to a better standard of quality for about 30 per cent or 40 per cent of the cost of the overseas product.

While in Gladstone, we also met with representatives of Comalco. The meeting was refreshing because, with the government's $100 million incentive program on the table, Comalco outlined its preference for Gladstone over Malaysiaâproviding the sums add up with the provision of energy from the pipeline. Another exciting project we visited is one that is very important to my electorate and to Australia in terms of future job creationâthe Stuart shale oil operation at Gladstone. It is a very exciting project which could make Australia self-sufficient for its oil requirements into the next century. Just think of the good that that would do our current account deficit!

This projectâwhich is based on a resource estimated at three billion barrels of oilâis I am proud to say being given a helping hand by the government. It was the second Gladstone project after Comalco to receive major project facilitation status. The minister and I toured a $250 million demonstration plant which will extract oil from shale and produce 4,500 barrels a day. Full commercial production by the year 2007-08 will require an investment of $2.5 billion and will create 2,000 jobs. The first oil is expected to be produced in the fourth quarter of this year and, if successful, stage 2 will produce 1,500 barrels a day, increasing to 85,000 barrels a day in stage 3, at which time it would be considered a full-scale commercial operation.

The oil is stored in the shale in the form of kerogen. The process of extracting the oil from shale, which involves heating the rock to 500 degrees Celsius, has been known for centuries. The first major commercial application started in Scotland in 1850 and ran until 1960. Deposits were discovered in Australia in 1802 in New South Wales, with commercial production growing to 16 mines between 1865 and 1952, when the last mine at Glen Davis was closed. These mines became uneconomical in the face of conventional oil discovery throughout the world.

The shale deposits discovered in Queensland and owned by Southern Pacific Petroleum and Central Pacific Minerals are vaster than any found before, are easier to mine, are closer to infrastructure and are expected to produce a cleaner and better product using cutting edge technology. There are 10 deposits totalling 28 billion barrels of oil. This will go a long way towards Australia's energy self-sufficiency, which is vital when current production will run out in about 15 to 20 years time if we do not find alternative fields. That is a very sobering thought.

It is interesting to note that oil from the Middle East is dirtier than the SP/CPM. Their Canadian partner, Suncor Energy, say that they will be able to produce, from the Stuart shale oil deposit, a much cleaner fuel. Their tests have shown that emissions of carbon dioxide sulfur and particulates will be reduced with the use of this shale oil in Australia. The actual process itself involves open-cut mining and clean, dry, non-toxic shale from which the oil is removed. The waste can be returned to the mine void to allow the land to return to its natural state.

The process of shale involves no chemicals. It is energy self-sufficient, does not create tailing ponds or toxic waste and produces a clean oil, free from impurities such as nitrogen and sulfur. This is a very exciting project which I intend to speak on in future in the parliament. I welcome the visit of the minister to my electorate, as indeed I would welcome the visit of all ministers, including the minister at the table, Mr Vaile, in his new manifestation. I commend the community of Gladstone for its reception of industry and its support of clean and continuing industry.

talk.start.para: âI want to talk tonight about manufacturing in Australia. Before I do that, I would like to express my appreciation both to you, Mr Deputy Speaker Mossfield, and to the member for Hinkler, as members of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform, on your visit to Newcastle last week to look at the national infrastructure and capacity. I am appreciative that fellow parliamentarians go to the trouble of actually finding out what is on the ground and what is happening in our regional centres. Too few people in this House know enough about those issues. So, on behalf of my community, I express my appreciation to those of you who went to that troubleâand there were quite a lot of you.

speech.para: We still see the debate in Australia about manufacturing as being caught up, if you like, in a bit of a time warp. People still think of manufacturing as involving factories with blue-collar workers, lots of dirt and smoke, and low skills. That has not been the case for quite some time. Modern manufacturing is essentially an assembly process, where companies draw components from all over the region, all over the country and even all over the world. They assemble those components into products which they then dispatch to regions and to the world. It is no longer done in one factory; it is done by a number of manufacturers and comes together eventually in assembling.

Looking at where world manufacturing is going in terms of development, and looking at what we do as a nation in terms of our policies to check our compatibility, it is quite obvious that we are not adequately in step with trends. Attempts to bring us in step have not been that successful. I want to refer particularly to events in the last 18 months in a moment.

The other part that is really quite critical to manufacturing has been the development and the role of quality processes. Until the last 10 or 15 years, companies throughout the world marketed on their brand name. If it was a Siemens product or a Philips product, then one could be assured it was probably of pretty decent quality. That made it very difficult for smaller manufacturers and smaller countries to take part in global distribution. However, with the development and expansion of quality assurance and quality codes, we have international standards. If met by a company, whether it employs 20 people or 2,000 people, the standards are the same. The quality assurance system has allowed Australian manufacturers to compete with the world's best because they can be amongst the world's best, and measurably so.

You no longer have to spend a fortune on advertising to establish a brand name, so long as you can establish that your quality assurance meets international standards. Our companies have done that in a massive way. In the Hunter Valley, for example, if you check with Quality Australia you will find that 15 or 20 years ago we had probably half a dozen companies with quality assurance. The last time I checked it, more than a year ago, we had over 540âin other words, 100 times more in the last 15 or 20 years. That is a major shift, not just in capacity but in attitude and understanding.

I wanted to get back to the process of how we design our systems to facilitate and encourage modern manufacturing. Back in 1996 the Newcastle community, particularly in conjunction with BHP as part of their Steel River development, put forward a proposal for a scheme for a foreign trade zone. The initial reaction around Canberra was shock, horror: `That sounds like a duty-free zone and that does not work, therefore we will say no.' That was the Prime Minister's response at the time.

It took a lot of time and a lot of effort to explain to people that what was being talked about was a deferred duty zone, where the duty on products coming into the country that were to be used in a manufacturing process should be deferred until the products were actually finalised. So, rather than having to pay up-front duties on components and then hold those in store for long periods while they were being used, the duty would be deferred until a product was completed and then paid when it entered the domestic marketplace.

There was a lot of discussion and argument. Members may well recall the steel committee chaired by the member for Wannon that looked at the future of steel. It picked up that recommendation and in a bipartisan way supported it to government and to the minister. The government then in, I think, December 1997 announced in the `Investing in growth' statement a proposal for what was called `manufacturing in bond' where the duty on components and imports could be deferred. This would allow manufacturing in bond, which was effectively a manufacturing bond store. What we had been arguing for was, effectively, a virtual bond store, not a physical boundary.

One can recall the old bond stores in the customs system. When people brought things to the docks, as soon as they crossed the barrier onto the wharf the importer had to pay the duty, whatever that might be. They had the option of putting it into a bond store, and whilst it was in that bond store the duty was not paid. The duty was not paid until it left the bond store, which effectively extended the physical boundary. Customs' function for hundreds of years has been to collect the dutyâwhether it was on rum, on imported cars or whatever. So the barrier approach and mentality was quite critical to Customs' functioning and their role.

What we have been trying to put forward, effectively, is to see the barrier not as at the aircraft or at the aerodrome or the wharf but, rather, as a computer stock control system. Products coming into the country to be used in the manufacturing process could then be tracked via a computer stock control system, and when they left the factory door the government could then charge duty as if they were being freshly imported, and at same rate.

We did not achieve that. What we achieved in manufacturing in bond went part of the way, but there were a couple of quite serious flaws in what the government adopted. The worst flaw was the fact that Customs was still charging a processing charge. So you had to pay to tell Customs that you had imported something and then exported it again. That in many cases would, in fact, be more than the tariffs that would be chargeable. It makes us a very unattractive place in which to invest in regional manufacturing if, in fact, you are going to pay a charge to advise that you are bringing things into the country and then pay again when you advise you are sending them out of the countryâa pretty fruitless gesture in a modern manufacturing context.

The government a year laterâin fact, in about Marchâaccepted that this was a weakness. So we have had 16 months of argument between December 1997 and March to April 1999. The government has now announced is going to amend its charges so that the processing charge does not apply to goods which are exported again. However, in that process there is a series of other mattersâfor example, consumables. A duty will be charged on the material that is actually used in the manufacturing process. For example, a manufacturer of, say, computers will import components from around the world and particularly around the region. At the moment, having got parts into the country, the duty on those can be deferred with manufacturing in bondâbut only in a physical location, not in a virtual bond store as we would desire. Having done that, they then pay duty on the solder and on the other parts that they use which are consumed in the process. On the other hand, their competitor who imports a fully made up computer that is completed does not.

So the cost of our manufacturing is still higher. It is obvious that what is happening here is that the government still sees the importing process as a revenue process not as a manufacturing process. The system has changed. The world has moved on. We were trying to move with it. We started, and there have been some very serious hiccups. In recent weeks I was fortunate enough to visit Ireland and to speak to a number of people from the Irish customs department, for which I am very grateful. I also visited the Shannon foreign trade zone, in which 20,000 people now work. Their system is based largely on a less refined model of the kind we are talking about now. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âIn the aftermath of the New South Wales drugs summitâwhich the Premier, Mr Carr, ought to be commended for conductingâI rise to stimulate the parliament to think about some of the issues in relation to the drug epidemic that is sweeping the country. The question needs to turn to why young people increasingly prefer the excitement that they believe drugs offer them to an unclouded consciousness. I recently read a book entitled Saving Jessie by Imogen Clark. It was sent to me by Doubleday, its publishers. It tells the story of a mother's battle to understand and cope with her daughter's heroin addiction. In reflecting on the ordeal, her own reaction to it and the impact on her family, Clark says what so few seem to understand:

speech.para: Jessie experimented with drugs because it was exciting, different and daring to do so. She persisted because it felt so good.
Clark rhetorically asks after Jessie finally kicks her habit:
Is she better? Not yet. She will never be cured. She will always be an addict. She will always be taking it a day at a time. And so will we.

Plans from some of my constituents to round up drug addicts andâif not shoot themâship them off to the desert ignore the fact that, until a person is emotionally ready to deal with their addiction, society's good intentions are at best futile. Having listened over the years to numerous parents tell the story of their child's drug use, what stands out is the ignorance of what was happening in the child's life when the drug use started. I wonder whether, in this climate of mutual obligation, some thought could be given to making the $50 back to school payment in New South Wales conditional on the discharge of some kind of parental responsibility. At the moment you do not even have to be poor to get it; you just have to be a parent.

Some parents seem to park their kids in primary school and then pick them up in year 12 when they come out the other end, having had absolutely no understanding of and, worse still, no interest in what was happening to their child as they went through their most important formative years. I thought that the $50 back to school payment could be increased to perhaps $100 and that, in order to get that $100, at least one parent be required to register for, and participate in, a school based or perhaps community based orientation program with very much a life skills content to teach parents what their children would be taught about drug education in the coming year, what drugs are available, where they can get help and what they need to know about the development of their child.

Those families who did not register or express an interest in such a program could be identified as being `at risk' families. Alternatively, a minimum commitment could be required of parents to participate in the life of the school. Sure, we are all busy, but at the Nar-Anon meetings that I have attended over the yearsânot that I have had a problemâI have been struck by the fact that, all too often, the first time parents knew their child had a problem was when they got a call from the police to advise them that their daughter or son was in trouble or, worse still, that they were dead.

If people think that in some way this is a little bit extreme, I direct you to research done by the Victorian Centre for Adolescent Health last year. They surveyed year 8 students 13 to 14 years of age. Forty per cent said that they did not know a single person who knew them well, and a quarter said that there was not a single personâfriend, teacher or parentâwhom they felt that they could trust. So the challenge to most parents that lies behind this idea is: do you know the deepest fear that is harboured by your son or your daughter? What is their favourite music, leisure activity or sport? What is their favourite place? Whom do they most admire and why?

I would also like to say that amongst the many real issues that seemed to elude the major political combatants during the recent New South Wales state election is one that goes to the heart of the problem. The problem is the kind of society we have become and, perhaps more importantly, the aspirations we hold for the world that we leave our children. In its 16 March edition, the Daily Telegraph featured a photograph of two ageing grim-faced men. Each wore medals of war service as they stood defiantly before an empty swimming pool complex. The site houses not only swimming pools from which once came the laughter of children but also a monument erected in memory of a local soldierâA.E. Smithâwho was killed while serving in the Boer War. The pools were built to honour men and women who served this nation in the Second World War. Liverpool Council is in the process of selling the site to Canterbury-Bankstown Leagues Club for the erection of a $100 million hotel complex into which will be installed 1,000 poker machines. Council has been held up not by the protest from the Premier of New South Wales under pressure from the opposition, but by problems with vehicle access.

New South Wales has just held a drug summit. Its focus was on how to deal with the problem, but much less on why young people are taking drugs at an unprecedented level in the first place. Some participants spoke during the summit of the signals we send young people. There are few more powerful than this one. Late last year at the Penrith Leagues Club I addressed an audience of 400 decent, concerned people on the issue of drugs. The aching question from the audience was: why are our kids taking drugs? I suggested that they did not have to go too far for clues. In order to get to the auditorium I had to walk through rows and rows of poker machines into which frequently heavily smoking individuals were pushing their pension cheques and low income dollars with a cold beer standing by the side of the machine. Then we gather in anguish to ask: why are our kids taking drugs?

The future of the Memorial Swimming Complex is critical because subtle yet powerful forces mould young people's resilience. In elevating gambling to the status of religion, we reinforce the growing view amongst the next generation that, whatever we may say, value is indeed more important than values. Liverpool does not need another poker machine any more than it needs another young person to abandon an idealistic hope that we care about their welfare more than we do about money. At Killarney Swim Centre they have a sign that says: `Our aim is not to produce a champion, but to provide an atmosphere where champions are inevitable.' However, swimming is a means to an end: to build self-confidence, self-discipline, integrity and courage for life. I have yet to see such a sign displayed in a gambling complex.

The Prime Minister recently weighed into the private school drug issue in response to things that had occurred at Pymble Ladies College within my electorate. His involvement in this issue is, in my view, more necessary as it gets closer to the disease of which drug use is the symptom. If we are going to have a war on drugs, the real war is yet to begin. The real war begins by seeking to answer the question: what is it that is building a despondent disillusionment in the present generation and a forlorn sense of hopelessness about the future in the next generation?

In this parliament every day we have a debate about progress, about economic growth. We celebrate the fact that at the moment our country is growing at a sustained and unprecedentedly high level. But the question which is not posed and that young people require us to answer is: toward what do we strive to make progress? What sort of country is it that we are actually trying to build? Is it one that is both idealistic and achievable? Is it based on values and principles that give young people the power to feel that the future is very much theirs to shape? This country is four times wealthier per head of population than it was a century ago, yet confidence in the future is a minority position amongst young people in every survey taken of their attitudes over the last five years. If we want to get to the bottom of the drug issue, this is part of it.

What is proposed for the Liverpool swimming centre, the way we spend our back to school parenting allowance and a whole range of issues like these send very strong yet powerful messages to young people about how we value them and the importance we place upon them. It is easy to become a parent. It is very difficult to be a good oneâyou do not have the skills until you finish the job. But if we are going to give people money for doing nothing and for being a parent, let us at least require them to discharge some degree of parental responsibility and, in doing so, we might be able to give young people the hope and the belief that their parents actually do care about them and have a concern for their future.
