As I indicated before, the opposition supports accrual accounting but this budget gives us the abolition of the forward estimates, a substantial reduction in the volume of very important information that previously was provided to the community, a balance sheet that has been perverted by ideological bias to grossly undervalue Telstra as an asset and value it at its true level on the basis of its being sold, meaningless performance indicators and a failure to address the very serious concerns raised by the Auditor-General with respect to the management of payments to the states. Under the guise of the introduction of accrual accounting, this government has reduced the information in the budget, reduced the level of transparency in the public accounting arena and reduced public accountability generally.

This leaves the question of the substance of the budget, which is equally deficient. This is essentially a complacent budget and, because of its reliance on the tax package, an inherently unfair budget. It assumes no improvement in employment. It assumes unemployment stuck at 7Â½ per cent. It forecasts lower business investment, lower household savings and lower government investment in research and development. In spite of the fact that the government has increased the funding to the National Health and Medical Research Council, since this government took office the amount of public funded research and development in overall terms has dropped from 0.78 per cent to 0.61 per cent of GDP.

In other words there has been a substantial reduction in overall government funding to the core driver of innovation, creativity and economic growth that is widely recognised now as a critical component of economic prosperity in countries such as ours. Instead we have consumption driven growth. The foundations for sustainable growth which could be being built through improvements in quality in education, increasing access to higher education and greater investment in research and development and in scientific and technological research are not being laid. Since 1996 this government has laid waste to the things that provide the foundations for sustainable growth and now the fiscal consolidation that has been built on cuts to these investments is being thrown away in generous tax cuts to high income earners and in sweetening a tax package that imposes a 10 per cent tax on virtually everything we buy.

We are told by the Treasurer that the economy has been fireproofed. Unfortunately, this is something of a mirage. We are told, for example, that our export profile has diversified andâisn't it wonderfulâjust as Asia is going down the tube, we have managed to increase our exports to Europe to balance it. This is more superficial than real because, for example, a substantial proportion of this trend is explained by the fact that large quantities of gold from Korea were imported into Western Australia to be reprocessed and then sold mostly in Amsterdam but overwhelmingly in Europe. That gets recorded as an import and then as an export. That is a highly unusual circumstance. It is unlikely to be repeated but that shows up in the accounts as a diversification of our exports. We cannot rely on these things as the basis for future assumptions.

As the honourable member for Corangamite mentioned, the current account deficit is now at record levels. We are told by some conservative economic commentators that this does not matter any more because the budget is in surplus. It used to matter when the budget was in deficit and we were told that putting the budget in surplus would cure the current account deficitâthe twin deficits theory. We now have a surplus, as we had in the late 1980s in the wake of the high current account deficits then. It seems yet again that the infamous twin deficits theory has failed us.

As I pointed out, we have seen a substantial cut in investment in education, in research and development and in all of the foundations which provide long-term growth and sustainability; once again, not a fireproofed economy but a fragile economy. We face the prospect of interest rate increases in the United States, the threat of collapse in overvalued securities on Wall Street, ongoing stagnation and reform problems in Japan and a range of other factors which are very likely to negatively influence Australia's economic prospects in the next few years, and we are told that this is a fireproofed economy.

This is a typical Liberal government budget. There is no investing for the future, there are big tax cuts for the rich and there are no constructive tax changes, for example in the business tax area, that would generate employment and increase investment. There is a new tax on everything that is regressive, that hits ordinary low income earning Australians worst and, to top it all off, there is a substantial reduction in the amount of information that is provided in the budget to both the parliament and the Australian community.

And now to superimpose on this complacent, this unfair, this regressive budget, we have the modified tax package where an awful lot of simplicity and efficiency, such as there was, has been traded away for the appearance of a marginal increase in fairness. We now have the new national sport, just in time for the Olympics, to find out which food is GST free and which food is not. Which part of the chook is in and which part is out? If the sausage has breadcrumbs on it, does it have a GST? Stayed tuned for the next exciting episode.

We are seeing unintended consequences of a well-meaning but ultimately misguided attempt to modify the appalling environmental consequences of the reduction in tax on fuel, particularly diesel. In fact, it will create a situation where the costs for buses, for public transport in urban Australia, will go up nine per cent rather than five per cent, as they would have under the previous tax package, therefore exacerbating the already strong drift away from public transport.

We are seeing the government renege on its promises to the states about funding the abolition of various state taxes and, of course, we are seeing the surplus dipped into by $1.4 billion, on top of the $5 to $7 billion that has already been taken out of the surplus to finance the tax cuts. And still, in spite of the protestations of the Democrats, we have a 10 per cent tax on virtually everything and income tax cuts which give the vast bulk of the proceeds to high income earners. The Democrats claim to have saved the tax package, to have saved the Howard government from itself, when in fact what they have done is renege on their principles and their promises.

They have betrayed their supporters, people such as the Australian Society of Authors who believed the Democrats' commitment that they would not vote for a new tax on books. They betrayed their party membership who believed their commitment that they would not vote for a GST on food, when that is precisely what they are now going to vote for. They have betrayed the Australian electorate, particularly those voters who believed that the Democrats would stick to what they said was non-negotiable in their pre-election statements about the tax package. The Democrats had six points of non-negotiability, they have run away from virtually all of them. They have delivered a little proportion of a couple of them and none of the rest. The end result is a tax package that is regressive and unfair to go with a budget that is complacent and unfair. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Mr Entsch) adjourned.

debate.para: Motion (by Mr Entsch) proposed:
That the House do now adjourn.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Student Demonstrations

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to speak tonight in this adjournment debate and I want to begin by asking this question: who made the following statement, `The government wants a totalitarian regime'? I will give you a clue. It was in the Bulletin in an article called `The world according to Meg Lees', written by John Lyons, in the very recent edition of 1 June 1999 which came out this week. Today we saw the real world according to Senator Lees, not the world of fairness and equity, not the world of tolerance, not the world of democratic rights. Why should we be surprised? We should not be surprised because, as that great Labor Premier Neville Wran said, `If you lie down with dogs, you get up with fleas.' The Democrats have lain down with the dog and tonight we have seen the fleas, but no number of dog collars can get these fleas off because ordinary Australians will not only shut them out of their houses, their residences; they will also shut them out of their houses of parliament.

speech.para: Today we saw the National Union of Students organise peaceful demonstrations against the GST in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and Adelaide. In Adelaide, the demonstration was at the office of Senator Lees. Not surprisingly, they were not home. The Democrats were missing. No-one was there. In Melbourne, Senator Allison was there, and the students occupiedâpeacefullyâthe office of Senator Allison for about an hour and a half, and she came out and had a discussion with them. In Sydney, we saw a very different story. We have seen on television tonight quite horrific scenes which occurred at the Democrats' New South Wales state office in Crows Nest, Sydney. We have seen scenes of 29 students arrested for peacefully demonstrating in the democratic country of Australia. Once the students went into those offices today, they were given a 50-second warning: they could either walk peacefully or they could be sprayed with capsicum. What those students chose to do was, of course, to walk peacefully. We saw it tonight: no resisting arrest, no violenceânothing except peaceful students chanting, `Tax the greedy, not the needy. No GST'- something that will echo around Australia in the coming months. It was a peaceful demonstration and yet these students have been charged with trespass and they have to appear before the court on 29 June this year.

I think that the Democrats' rhetoric about being a political party who care about democracy and who care about the right to peaceful demonstration is in tatters tonight, just as their credibility as being a party which is committed to their own democratic processes is in tatters. It is no wonder that it occurred in New South Wales, because today we saw reports that the party's New South Wales council has condemned the tax package deal, one day after this sleazy deal was done. On Saturday it said, `It does not reflect the views of this council.' The New South Wales resolution was moved not by a rank and file member, not by some Johnny-come-lately, but by the state secretary, Mr Manny Poularas, who predicted that Senator Lees would be `done like a dinner' by the Prime Minister. She would want to be careful, because whether things are cooked or not is very relevant in terms of the GST. But the fact is that the state secretary of the Democrats' New South Wales branchâthe biggest branchâhas said, `The Democrats won't do as well out of this deal as they think.'

I raise a questionâjust a questionâto Senator Stott Despoja, the darling of the student movement before today. What is her stance on this issue? What is her stance when students are marched out of a peaceful demonstration, in handcuffs, charged with trespass? I was an ALP assistant secretary for seven years, and we had demonstrations in the ALP office constantly because we respected people's democratic rights to participate and to protest. (Time expired).

talk.start.para: âI would like to draw the attention of the House to a matter of enormous importance to not only the people of Redcliffe but all Queenslanders. As many members here would no doubt be aware, tonight's edition of A Current Affair ran a story about the backflow problems in some of Queensland's public buildings. Some of these buildings are hospitals and primary schools. There are, as the story on A Current Affair pointed out, serious concerns over the safety of the water supply in over 1,000 of these buildings. This is particularly the case at two hospitalsâthe Gympie and Redcliffe hospitals, the latter being in my electorate.

speech.para: The backflow problem basically occurs when there is a reverse in the flow of contaminated water back into the main water supply. A report commissioned by the state government in August last year found that this problem exists in buildings such as the Redcliffe Hospital, and it has reached the point where lives are at risk. The report concluded that fluids such as formaldehyde, disinfectants, chemicals used in X-ray development and even bodily fluids could flow back into the water supply with deadly consequences. One would have thought that, with such advice, the minister responsible for this, Mr Schwarten, would have hastened any attempts to fix the problem. One would have even thought that the Labor member whose constituents are at risk would have ensured that this was the case. But this has not happened. Instead, Mr Schwarten has referred the matter to a committee and cancelled the original firm's contract. In doing so, he has effectively doubled the amount of time it will take to fix the problem. And not a word has been said by the state member for Redcliffe.

We now have on the Redcliffe peninsula a hospital that has a potentially deadly water supply, thanks to the administrative incompetence of the state Labor government and the inaction of the member for Redcliffe. What concerns me, though, is not only the immediate risk to the people on the peninsula but the risk to all Queenslanders. This is just another example of Labor's mismanagement at a state level.

Over the past few months, there have been a number of glaringly stupid and ideologically blinkered decisions taken by the Beattie government which have jeopardised the quality of life of many peninsula residents. Take, for example, the rather bizarre situation that occurred very recently of undermanning the Redcliffe police force on weekends. The state member for Redcliffe, Ray Hollis, made much hue and cry two to three weeks about his efforts in getting the state police minister, Tom Barton, to address the recent crime spree. There were, judging by comments in the local press, a number of options that would be looked at. One of the options that was not mentioned was the option of user-pays policing.

The local Redcliffe business community recently banded together in an effort to address what is seen by many as Redcliffe's poor public image. In conjunction with the Redcliffe City Council, a number of businesses helped to fund a $125,000 advertising campaign to promote Redcliffe. Imagine the indignation felt by these peopleâthe hardworking small business people of Redcliffeâwhen the news emerged that, if they wanted just one extra policeman to patrol the Redcliffe CBD on Friday and Saturday, they would have to pay for it. The state government would not pay for it. The small business community would have to foot the bill, at the rate of $50 an hour, just to get an off-duty policeman to patrol the CBD. One would have thought that the state taxes that businesses pay would entitle them to have their premises protected by a police presence. But apparently not. This, the Labor Party's ability to continually botch up the operation and the quality of services at Redcliffe hospital are just further examples of Mr Beattie's and Mr Hollis's disregard for the whole of the Redcliffe peninsula.

talk.start.para: âEarlier this month I spent a couple of days in Macedonia. This country is one of very few successful multi-ethnic democracies in the Balkans region. Of course, it is a region that is presently attracting considerable focus because of the crisis focused on its immediate neighbour to the north, Kosovo. I visited the Macedonia-Kosovo border and witnessed thousands of Kosovo refugees at the border in the process of crossing. I also had the opportunity to see and visit thousands of additional refugees in the largest camp in Macedonia at a place called Stenkovec. I certainly heard the NATO planes overhead.

speech.para: In Australia, the plight of the refugees has quite naturally attracted the greatest deal of attention and, indeed, their plight is horrific. But the world very much needs to fully understand that the crisis is threatening the economic and social future of Macedonia and other countries in the region. It is not just the impact of a quarter of a million additional people in a country of only two million peopleâon a pro rata equivalent that would be 2.7 million refugees in Australiaâbut it is the massive social and economic costs of the crisis that are feeding into other aspects of Macedonia's life.

Yugoslavia is a major trading partner of Macedonia and a huge percentage of Macedonia's trade with other countries passes through Yugoslavia. Even if the crisis were to cease tomorrow, the damage to the infrastructure of the region means that it will be a substantial amount of time before opportunities for economic activity return to any normalcy. Certainly, it is worth noting that a substantial part of Macedonia's agricultural produce used to go to Kosovo, but no longer. Foreign direct investment has largely dried up as a result of the crisis. According to the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, GDP in Macedonia is now expected to contract by four per cent in this year compared to an estimated five per cent growth prior to the conflict.

The current account balance is likely to deteriorate, compared to last year, by $US220 million rather than the $US40 million improvement that had been expected before the crisis. The government budget is now facing massive pressures from declining revenues and additional expenditures associated with the crisis. For example, costs of providing services to refugees, in addition to humanitarian aid projects, is estimated at some $US50 million this year as a direct cost to the Macedonian budget, and this against the background of a country which up until the crisis had the highest rate of unemployment in Europe. The terrible social consequences of higher unemployment will continue to impact.

World Bank documents indicate that the financing gap for 1999 is likely to be around $US440 million. Earlier this month in Paris, Western governments met and promised about $250 million in grants and loans. Earlier, the US had pledged $44 million. This is quite inadequate in terms of the crucial demands that are being placed on the economy of that country and of its neighbours. They are countries that are absolutely crucial to regional stability and stability through the world. I think it is worth noting that the $250 million that has been pledged is only a very small percentage of the cost of the war itself. I understand the `cheques are still in the mail', as it were, and that, at this stage, in terms of direct support to the Macedonian budget sector, only $2 million has been received and that from Taiwan.

Australia, quite rightly, is doing its bit on the refugee question but we need to vigorously press with the rest of the West, broadly defined, the need to recognise the disastrous implications of allowing Macedonia's economy and society to continue to decline. A development and reconstruction strategy akin, I would suggest, to the Marshall Plan after the Second World War is required for the Balkans region, including Macedonia. Western Europe, which was the beneficiary of that post Second World War reconstruction strategy, ought to be focusing a great deal more on the long-term development strategies required to seriously address the fundamental problems of the Balkans and not simply focus on the war.

This is a part of the world that is a long way from Australia but I think many of us have substantial numbers of Macedonian constituents in our electorates and this is the area Australia ought to focus on. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to congratulate the government on measures it has taken to reduce the likelihood of residents being caught unprepared for natural disasters. These are particularly welcome following the hailstorm which occurred on 14 April this year in Sydney. Nearly 800 homes in my electorate of Cook were damaged in that storm, with the suburb of Lilli Pilli suffering the most damage. I doorknocked homes of many residents there shortly afterwards to see if there was anything I could do. In some streets in that area, like Swan and Koala roads, every house was damaged by hailstones, some the size of cricket balls. One couple had moved a few years ago to Lilli Pilli after bushfires had destroyed their home. Another resident finished mopping up the mess caused by their spare bedroom ceiling caving in when their kitchen ceiling also gave way. The message I got from local residents was that, overall, people were very happy with the work done by the state's emergency workers, and the various insurance companies, in terms of their quick response.

speech.para: Sutherland shire had crews working non-stop after the hailstorm. The 66 paid and volunteer workers were out in the rain trying to help people secure their homes from the elements. They were doing a terrific job, and I believe that we would all want to congratulate them for being out there for the community. It is a great shame that the media tried to paint a negative picture of the SES response. In my own electorate, early in the week following the storm, only four houses were yet to be attended out of a total of 1,379 calls for help that were logged, and three of those calls had been placed that day. To me, that is an excellent response rate.

The government has delivered on its 1998 election commitment to continue support for the implementation of key recommendations of the 1996 review of the operation of the Bureau of Meteorology. The government has, amongst other things, provided an additional $4.6 million a year for three years in response to the review; established with the CSIRO a joint high performance computing and communications centre to provide Australia with world-class weather computing systems; and funded improvements to the Bureau of Meteorology's vital cyclone, flood, severe storms and fire public warning services.

I also congratulate the Assistant Treasurer on his announcement that donations to the Natural Disaster (Sydney Hail Storm Assistance) Fund will be tax deductible. The federal government will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to allow deductions for donations to the fund for a period of two years, subject to the fund satisfying the usual public fund requirements. The severe hailstorm that caused immense damage to property has created an urgent need for assistance. The government considers the disaster serious enough to specifically list the fund by name in the Income Tax Assessment Act rather than the fund being approved under the general category of `a necessitous circumstances fund'. This approach will allow a speedier payment of moneys to those determined to be eligible for assistance. By specifically listing the fund, benefits can be provided to businesses and community groups, which would not be possible under normal disaster relief circumstances.

A new Doppler radar system has been constructed at Kurnell in my electorate which will help the Bureau of Meteorology pinpoint oncoming southerly winds before they hit the city. This will give accurate information about their strength and structure so emergency crews can alert residents in time for them to take precautionary measures to avoid damage. It was unfortunate that, shortly after the storm hit Sydney, some people chose to point the finger at some of my constituents for holding up the installation of the new radar. In 1997, 144 residents petitioned the Sutherland Shire Council not to accept the new installation, based on unfounded fears raised previously in other electorates about radiation emissions. Once the concerns of my local residents were addressed, the council approved construction of the site.

People are perfectly within their rights to ask their local council to respond to public safety concerns before allowing construction plans to proceed. The leader of the lobby group opposing the construction of the tower, Mark Kenny, was merely responding to opposition from people near sites, including Macquarie University, that had previously been considered. I rather think that Kurnell residents should be congratulated for accepting their council's assessment and ceasing their opposition so quickly. I am delighted with the responses that were given by the SES workers throughout the hail affected area, and certainly I know that the people of Cook would want to join me in widespread congratulations to the team involved.

talk.start.para: âThe recent drug summit in New South Wales gave a degree of endorsement for trials of safe injecting rooms for injecting drug users. While these initiatives have been supported by local community leaders in inner city areas of Sydney, in the Cabramatta area where drug use is very high community leaders have expressed their opposition to trials of a safe injecting room going ahead. Opposition to safe injecting rooms in Cabramatta is based on the idea that they would attract drug users to the area. It ignores the fact that Cabramatta is the centre of drug distribution in Sydney and heroin is more readily available and less expensive there than elsewhere in Sydney. These factors are the main attraction of Cabramatta and will remain so, regardless of the presence of safe injecting rooms. Safe injecting rooms save lives. That is the clear message from overseas trials. That is the clear message from local health authorities. That is why the New South Wales drug summit was left with the conclusion that trials of safe injecting rooms should go ahead.

speech.para: Each year in the Cabramatta area dozens of young lives are lost through drug overdose. Many of these deaths are preventable if immediate medical attention can be given to victims of drug overdose. Safe injecting rooms, at the very least, allow injecting drug users to be observed for signs of overdose. Early treatment can then be sought, leading to a much greater chance of successful recovery for overdose victims. The risk of overdose is also reduced when drug users can properly measure and prepare their dose. If these deaths were the result of anything other than drug overdose, there would be a public outcry for action to be taken. But our society has adopted a double standard for human lifeâone for drug addicts and one for the rest of us. No civilised society can stand back and do nothing when human lives are being needlessly lost. No community can claim to have civic pride when it stands in the way of measures which save human lives. No parent should allow the life of another's child to be put at risk for the unlikely reason that it sends the wrong message to their own child.

The need for a safe injecting room in the Cabramatta area was brought home to me recently in a discussion I had with the mother of a drug user. She recently found out that her son was using heroin when she received a call from a hospital to say that her son was being treated for an overdose. Prior to that she had no idea that her son was using drugs. The shock of that discovery and the thought that she may have lost her son have had a dramatic effect upon her. She now has no alternative but to stand by while her son injects himself in his bedroom at home. As much as the thought of that occurring horrifies her, the alternative of her son injecting himself in an alleyway horrifies her even more. She prays for the chance for her son to enter a rehabilitation program and lives in constant fear of a call from a hospital with tragic news of her son.

A safe injecting room will save lives. It will result in fewer cases requiring intensive care treatment in our hospitals, freeing up much needed beds for other medical needs. It will reduce the risk of disease from needle sharing. It will reduce the number of discarded needles and the risk to the wider community of disease from them. Safe injecting rooms can also play a part in the rehabilitation of drug users. Through maintaining contact with drug users, the first steps towards rehabilitation may be taken. Rehabilitation depends on the desire of the user to quit. In a safe injecting room the choice and opportunity are always present: continue to use drugs or seek help. No other treatment alternative offers this stark choice. It is time for our local community leaders to take their heads out of the sand, to see what is happening around them and to have the courage to act to save young lives.

talk.start.para: âI was among the many in the chamber who noted the spontaneous applause which came from the galleries on the introduction of Mikhail Gorbachev today during question time. I also had the opportunity to listen briefly to some of his remarks upstairs earlier in the day. Mikhail Gorbachev is a symbol of the fact that history moves on, situations change and the sorts of settled certainties of life may not be as settled as they may appear. As a person who grew up during the Cold War, the idea of the Soviet Union was a permanent feature on the world's geopolitical horizon. Yet here was one man who had a different vision and a different view and who saw ultimately a free and democratic Russia. Clearly, there is a long way to go in that part of the world. There is a great deal of uncertainty, anxiety and difficulty in the former Soviet Union. But this one man, through his idea of glasnost, lit the sparkâwith the support of many of the independent peoples in the other countries of the region and with pressure from the Westâwhich eventually saw the collapse of the Soviet Union.

speech.para: We gather today in this place after the recent elections in Israel at which we have seen Ehud Barak from the Labour Party elected as Prime Minister of Israel. I grew up in a family which saw the Middle East largely through the Western media, through our close relationship with the United States, and so I grew up with a kind of instinctive preference for the Israeli position. Mr Speaker, I stand before you today as someone who still feels a deep loyalty to Israel and as a member of the Australia-Israel Friendship Group.

A couple of weeks ago I was approached by three of my colleagues from both sides of the House on the idea of creating an Australian Parliamentary Friends of Palestine Group, which was subsequently inaugurated. Tomorrow evening we meet together for the first time. As chairman of that group I want to reflect on the importance of the election result in Israel. It was, I think, an expression by the Israeli people of dissatisfaction with the pace of the peace process and with its lack of momentum, and to some extent it represents a rejection of the elements of intransigence in the former government. While I am reluctant to celebrate the election of a Labour government anywhere in the world, I certainly accept that this may signal the beginning of renewed momentum for peace in the Middle East.

We have heard during this adjournment debate about the problems of the refugees in Macedonia. We also ought to reflect on the fact that there are several million Palestinian refugees around the Middle East who tonight will be sleeping in barely covered shacksâmothers who are struggling to clothe, feed and adequately house their children. They are in that stateless and destitute position because of the inability to achieve peace in the Middle East.

So as a friend of Israel but nonetheless as a human being with, I hope, a sense of feeling for those in distress, for those who have suffered injustice anywhere in the world, I want to register my deep empathy with the Palestinian people. I know the concern of many in this chamber to see a just and lasting resolution to that Middle East problem. I want to congratulate Ehud Barak on his election as Prime Minister of Israel. This House stands solidly behind the peace process and wants to see a renewed momentum in that process. We want to see resolution of the question of the Palestinian refugees, the question of settlements in East Jerusalem, the question of the West Bank and the question of the capital, Jerusalemâall of those things are soluble. Mikhail Gorbachev stands as an example of one man who tested and challenged the status quo and who brought about a new era of freedom, of autonomy, of self-determination. I really hope that the election of Ehud Barak signals the beginning of a similar process for the Palestinian people. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThere are times in the history of this place when it is important to set aside the differences which normally exist between the respective political parties represented in this parliament. One of those issues is when we confront the reality of human suffering around the world, and most recently in that context the suffering that I have witnessed personally in North Korea.

speech.para: I spoke in the grievance debate here about two months ago about the famine in North Korea and said that estimates from the United Nations at that stage were that up to three million people had died out of a total national population of 22 million. That famine has been going on for some years now. Since first raising the issue in this chamber, I have had the opportunity to visit Pyongyang, the capital of North Korea, with my friend and colleague the member for Holt, the Hon. Gareth Evans. As a result of that visit, I have to report to the House that the situation in North Korea is as serious and as grave as anything that I have seen or previously considered to be possible.

North Korea is a strange place. It is a strange country; it has a repressive political system; it is probably the last vestige of Stalinism to be seen anywhere in the world. In North Korea today you see George Orwell alive and well in terms of what remains of the political structure. On the economic front, there is precious little prospect of change. You see very little evidence of economic reform.

On the humanitarian front, however, North Korea is confronting a major crisis. The World Food Program, with whom we spoke in North Korea and whose representatives cover the entire country, say that as we speak today there are some five million children in North Korea who are substantially dependent on UN delivered food aid in order to survive. In the period between April and July of this year they are almost exclusively dependent on UN delivered food aid. To put this in context, this is probably the largest humanitarian crisis we have seen in this region since the Great Leap Forward in China in 1958. This is a massive humanitarian crisis.

Upon our return to Australia we reported on these matters to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Downer. I would like to place on record my appreciation for the fact that, not long after that discussion, Mr Downer issued a statement saying he had allocated a further $4 million to humanitarian relief in North Korea. I also place on record that, as the crisis continues, I will be making a similar request of the minister again.

talk.start.para: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 23 November 1998;

question.para: (1) What was the total cost to the (a) Commonwealth and (b) Australian Taxation Office (ATO) of implementing the superannuation contributions surcharge including salaries, systems, advertising, liaison, outrider agency costs, legal and accounting.
(2) What is the estimated cost to the superannuation industry of implementing the surcharge provisions.
(3) What sum was collected from surchargeable contributions in 1997-98.
(4) What sum is estimated to be collected from surchargeable contributions in (a) 1998-99, (b) 1999-2000. and (c) 2000-2001.
(5) How many dead persons (a) have been levied with the surcharge and (b) will be required to pay the advance instalment.
(6) What special arrangements have been made to allow dead persons to recover the advance surcharge instalment.
(7) What are the details of the test cases the ATO is running on the surcharge and what will the test cases cost.
(8) How many due surcharge assessments had not been issued by the ATO as at 12 November 1998.
(9) How many surcharge assessments were issued to persons who did not provide their tax file number to their superannuation fund or the ATO.
(10) What is the estimated number of persons who have been issued with a surcharge assessment but who earn less than the threshold income.

talk.start.para: âThe Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) The Department of Finance and ComSuper have estimated the cost at $3.4m for the Superannuation schemes administered by them.

(1) (b) The ATO calculates it has expended the following amounts to develop, implement and administer the superannuation contributions surcharge (including policy development and communication, system build and IT operation costs, interpretation and client services, accounting, debt collection and enforcement activities): 1996-97â$2.127m; 1997-98â$12.467m; July 1998- to dateâ$8.691m.

(2) The cost to industry of implementing the surcharge provisions is unknown, although there are likely to be costs associated with introducing any new measure. Additional costs incurred in order to set up a fund to comply with legislated requirements can be regarded as start up costs and amortised over a number of years.
(3) The value of 1996/97 assessments issued was $454m of which $347m was collected by 30 June 1998. Amended and original 1996/97 assessments were issued in February 1999 to the value of $86m.

The amount collected since 1 July 1998 in respect of both the outstanding balance from the original assessments and from the assessments issued in February 1999 is $100m. The amount still outstanding includes $37m subject to objection, $16m subject to amendment/variation and $23m not yet due for payment.

(4) The estimates of the amounts to be collected from the surcharge measure as stated in the 1996/97 Budget papers were: 1997-98â$480m; 1998-99â$470m; 1999-00â$530m; 2000-01âno figures projected.

(5) (a) Surcharge assessments are based on information reported to the ATO by superannuation providers. If a provider has ceased to be the holder of contributions by the time an assessment is received then the assessment is taken not to have been made.
A provider ceases to be the holder of contributions if:
- a lump sum has been paid or a pension or annuity has begun to be paid before an assessment is received; or
- a member dies before an assessment is received by the provider.
A provider continues to be the holder of contributions and is liable to pay an assessed surcharge liability if it receives an assessment before:-
- a lump sum is paid;
- a pension or annuity has begun to be paid; or
- death benefits are paid.

(5) (b) There are no circumstances where an individual, as a holder of contributions, will be required to pay an advance instalment, irrespective of whether they are alive or dead (The Government has announced its intention to remove the requirement for the Commissioner of Taxation to determine an advance instalment. As a consequence no advance instalment will be determined in relation to surcharge assessed on or after 23 March 1999).

(6) There are no special arrangements in place. An advance instalment is not required to be paid if a member exits the superannuation system. If a person dies before a determination of advance instalment falls due for payment, then there is no need for the provider to pay the instalment.

If a person dies after an advance instalment has been paid, then the advance instalment will be credited in the next assessment to issue to the provider. If the provider notifies the ATO that the representative of the estate is now the holder of the contributions, then the advance will be refunded to that holder.

(7) As a result of the Assistant Treasurer announcing initiatives designed to simplify the operation of the surcharge legislation the ATO does not intend to proceed with any Test Cases in relation to the superannuation surcharge.
(8) Some 119,000 members have been impacted by original and amended 1996/97 surcharge assessments that issued in February 1999.

(9) In May 1999, the ATO expects to issue in the order of 66,500 assessments relating to contributions of members for whom a TFN has not been obtained; the ATO is confident these members will be high income earners, irrespective of whether they subsequently quote their TFN.
(10) None.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Pacific Economic Co-Operation: Australia's Individual Action Plan
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 379)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 8 February 1999:

question.para: (1) What are Australia's obligations under its APEC individual action plan for (a) tariff and (b) non-tariff measures.
(2) What progress has been made in fulfilling the obligations.

(3) How does Australia's obligations and progress, measured by unweighted average tariff rates, compare to (a) Hong Kong, (b) New Zealand, (c) Singapore, (d) Taiwan and (e) the United States of America.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Australia's APEC individual action plan does not impose any legally binding obligations on Australia. APEC is not a treaty-based organisation; it is a grouping of regional economies which share the common goal of free and open trade and investment in the Asia-Pacific no later than the year 2020 (with the industrialised economies to achieve the goal no later than the year 2010). This goal has the force of a commitment by APEC Leaders which has been reaffirmed every year since 1995. Individual Action Plans record the steps that APEC economies have taken (and intend to take) to reach this goal of free and open trade and investment.

The specific commitments that Australia has made in relation to (a) tariffs and (b) non-tariff measures are recorded in Australia's 1998 APEC Individual Action Plan which I tabled in Parliament on 11 November 1998.
(2) Australia's progress in implementing its Individual Action Plan commitments on tariffs and non-tariff measures is set out below:

. tariffs on passenger motor vehicles and component parts have been reduced from 25 per cent in 1996 to 17.5 per cent in 1999. They will be further reduced to 15 per cent on 1 January 2000 and 10 per cent on 1 January 2005;

. tariffs on textile, clothing and footwear products have been reduced from between 5 and 37 per cent in 1996-97 to between 5 and 31 per cent in 1998-99. Further reductions will occur on 1 July 1999, 1 July 2000 and (subject to the passage of legislation by Parliament) 1 January 2005;

. the out-of-quota tariff on certain cheeses has been reduced from $1.366 per kilogram in 1996 to $1.257 per kilogram in 1999. The out-of-quota tariff will be further reduced to $1.22 per kilogram on 1 January 2000;

. Australia has removed tariffs on all but six of the products covered by the Information Technology Agreement. Tariffs on the remaining six products will be removed on 1 January 2000 in accordance with Australia's obligations under the Agreement;
. a review of nuisance tariffs has concluded and the Government is examining the outcomes of the review;

. export controls have been removed on woodchips and other unprocessed wood derived from native forests in regions where Regional Forest Agreements are in place (Tasmania and the East Gippsland and Central Highlands regions of Victoria);
. export controls have been removed on plantation-sourced material grown in Victoria, Tasmania, South Australia, Western Australia, New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory.

(3) Australia's obligations and progress, measured by unweighted average tariff rates, compared to Hong Kong, China, New Zealand, Singapore, Chinese Taipei and the United States of America is shown in the following table:

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 February 1999:

question.para: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a discussion paper on the role of authorised marriage celebrants published in 1997; if so, what steps have been taken to encourage inactive and uninterested marriage celebrants to resign.
(2) What measures will be taken to ensure that only the best candidates are selected to be authorised marriage celebrants.
(3) Will an interview by a skilled personnel practitioner be included in the selection process.
(4) Will the provision of evidence that the applicant has studied and understands the celebrant's role be a criterion.
(5) What advice for prospective applicants is available to ensure that they are adequately prepared for the selection procedure.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Attorney-General is aware of the discussion paper in question.
Civil marriage celebrants are required to report on a six monthly basis and, from November 1997, the form used for these reports has included the question: "Do you wish to continue as a Celebrant?"

Since the question was included on the form, 27 civil marriage celebrants have indicated that they did not wish to continue and their authorisations have been revoked. Four others have resigned because of illness and four have been revoked because my Department has been unable to locate them despite extensive inquiries.

(2) Civil marriage celebrants are now appointed only to meet identified community need. When an area is identified as needing more civil marriage celebrants, my Department advertises in the local media inviting applicants and the applicants to be appointed are selected on merit.

(3) The current selection process is being reviewed in light of responses to the discussion paper and the suggestion that applicants be interviewed is one of the matters being assessed in this review.

(4) The current selection criteria include proven interpersonal skills, the ability to conduct wedding ceremonies with the appropriate dignity in a manner which enhances the occasion for all present, an understanding of the celebrant's role, ability to speak in public and the ability to understand, implement and to explain to clients the requirements of the Marriage Act and Regulations. Applicants who can provide evidence that they have successfully studied the celebrant's role would have an advantage in demonstrating these skills.
Training for existing and prospective celebrants, including the question of whether it should be compulsory, are key issues in the current review.

(5) Applications for authorisation as civil marriage celebrants are accepted only to meet identified community needs. Prospective applicants in areas where there is such a need are given an application package which includes the selection criteria and detailed instructions on the type of evidence required to demonstrate that the applicants meet those criteria.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation, upon notice, on 11 February 1999:

question.para: (1) What sum did the Australia Council grant to organisations for the employment of multicultural arts officers in each year from 1991-92.

(2) Will he provide details of the operation of the Australia Council's Community Development Program since its inception including the (a) total sum granted to organisations under the program, (b) names of organisations granted funds, (c) sum granted to each organisation, (d) period covered by each grant, (e) manner of selection of organisations, (f) individual, group or body specifically responsible for the selection of recipients and (g) criteria, guidelines or policies used in making selections.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (2) The Community Arts Board which began in the 1970s first funded Multicultural Arts Officers (MAOs) under the Ethnic Arts Officers program in 1987. In 1988 the Community Cultural Development Committee funded those positions under the Multicultural Arts Officers Program. In 1991 the Community Cultural Development Board was set up, which continued the program. In 1994-1995 the program ceased, and the MAOs were able to apply to, and were funded under, the "Creative Development: Organisers" program. When the Council restructured all its grant programs in 1996, this program was replaced by the Program Grants Category and is now known as the Triennial Grants Category.
Peer assessment at arm's length from government is the fundamental tenet of the Australia Council's structure and decision-making process.
(a) Total sum granted to organisations under the programs
1987 Ethnic Arts Officer program to 1999 Triennial Grants Program: $2,272,099
(b) Names of organisations granted funds are listed in the Australia Council Annual Reports (see summary table 1 attached)

(e) Manner of selection of organisation for each grant is as per the grants handbook current in the year in which the decision was made. Organisations which wished to be considered for funding completed an application form and lodged it with the Australia Council by the advertised closing date. Applications were then assessed in competition with each other, and the highest ranked applications funded. The Australia Council Support for the Arts Handbook, 1999 describes the assessment process as follows;
Assessment of your application

In making grant decisions the Funds and the Board will assess your application with regard only to the published selection criteria for the grant category to which you are applying, as set out in section 4 of this handbook.
Assessment of applications and final grant decisions are made by the relevant Fund or the Board primarily on the basis of the information supplied by you in your application.
Fund and Board members may also take into account information from other sources such as:
. their attendance at performances and other events;
. assessment reports from members of the Register of Peers who may be asked to provide formal assessments of designated works;
. reviews, videos and recordings, referee reports and other material; and
. any previous Australia Council grant acquittal reports and performance agreements you may have had.

While your application may meet the stated selection criteria, this does not guarantee you a grant. The Australia Council receives many more applications than it can support. The success of your application must rest ultimately on the merits of your proposal against published criteria and in competition with all the other applications considered for funding.

(f) The body specifically responsible for the selection of grants recipients to the programs listed above was: 1987âCommunity Arts Board; 1988â1990âCommunity Cultural Development Committee; 1991-1995âCommunity Cultural Development Board; 1996-1999âCommunity Cultural Development Fund.

(g) Criteria used in the making of selections has varied from program to program and year to year, and can be found in the Grants Handbook for each year. The Australia Council Support for the Arts Handbook, 1999 lists the following information in the Triennial Grants Category;

The purpose of this category is to further understanding of, and support innovation in, community cultural development practice by providing triennial funding to a limited number of outstanding organisations. By supporting these organisations the Fund aims to increase opportunities for communities to control and participate in their own cultural development.

Applicants must have a substantial record of achievement in community cultural development and be able to demonstrate that they have contributed to community cultural development through the artistic work they have produced and/or through the role they have played in fostering and developing work in the field.
Applicants may be community cultural development organisations, or organisations which have a community cultural development program or worker as a component of their broader activities.
Eligibility
This category is open to organisations.
Applicants must be able to demonstrate that at least 50% of their income is derived from sources other than the Funds or Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Arts Board of the Australia Council.
Applicants will be expected to have had a record of funding through the Australia Council and should have been awarded at least three grants from the Council within the last five years.
Selection Criteria
Applications will be selected that best demonstrate:
. a high level of achievement in the advancement and development of community cultural development practice;
. that the organisation is best placed to deliver services to a regional, State or national constituency;
. a capacity to stimulate critical debate about community cultural development practice;
. a strategy for increasing opportunities for communities to control and participate in their own cultural development;
. that the operations and services proposed are community-based and culturally inclusive; and
. effective management of finances and administration including a well developed three-year plan which includes strategies for accessing new resources and new sources of income.
P63 of the Handbook also advises that "It is unlikely the Fund will provide funding for community cultural development arts workers positions for more than two triennial periods."

(3) From the seven applications received by the Community Cultural Development Fund from previously funded MAO applicants to the Triennial Grants Category in 1998-1999, the Liverpool Migrant Resource Centre, was successful.

The six unsuccessful applications did not receive funding in that grant round because like other unsuccessful applicants, they did not compete against the selection criteria as strongly as those who did receive funding. In no instance is triennial funding `renewed' as each application is considered on its own merit, in competition with other applications received by the same closing date.
All unsuccessful triennial applicants have been encouraged to apply for project funding under other grants category programs.

There was no involvement of the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts or the Minister's office in the assessment of applications to the Community Cultural Development Fund's Triennial grants category. As listed in the 1999 Australia Council Support for the Arts Handbook;

While the Australia Council Act 1975 enables the Minister to give directions to the Council regarding performance of its functions or the exercise of its powers, these directions must not be in regard to particular grants, scholarships or other benefits.
A copy of the Australia Council's Arts for a Multicultural Australia policy is available on request.

subdebateinfo.title: 1998 Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race: Consultations
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 511)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, upon notice, on 23 March 1999:

question.para: Did the organisers of the 1998 Sydney to Hobart yacht race consult an agency or authority for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility before the race started; if so, (a) what information was provided and (b) did the agency or authority suggest then or subsequently that the timing of the race was dangerous or inappropriate in the circumstances.

talk.start.para: âThe Minister for the Environment and Heritage has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: Yes. The Cruising Yacht Club of Australia (CYCA) contacted the Bureau of Meteorology, an agency for which I have responsibility.

(a) The organisers requested the Bureau to provide a pre-race briefing and a special race forecast service to all competitors in the Sydney to Hobart yacht race. This special service has been provided for several years. The specific services for the CYCA were provided on a cost-recoverable basis (i.e. the incremental cost to the Bureau of providing the service was recovered from the CYCA) and included pre-race briefings by Bureau staff for the competitors and organisers and special access arrangements for race officials to contact the Bureau's Senior Forecaster at any time.

These specific services for the CYCA were in addition to the Bureau's normal provision of marine weather services, including coastal waters and high seas forecasts and warnings, and coastal weather reports, in the period leading up to and encompassing the yacht race.

(b) No. The Bureau of Meteorology has responsibility for providing guidance about meteorological conditions that individuals, groups or organisations use to make decisions most appropriate to these conditions. The Bureau issued a gale warning for part of the race area about four hours before the race start. This was upgraded to the first of a series of storm warnings about an hour after the start of the race. In addition to the storm warnings being disseminated through normal channels (eg radio, facsimile and Internet), Bureau staff telephoned the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, the Eden Royal Volunteer Coastal Patrol and the Sydney to Hobart Race media centre to ensure that search and rescue personnel, race officials and competitors had received the storm warning. This warning advised of wind increasing to 45/55 knots offshore south of Merimbula late Sunday afternoon. Wind speeds identified in Bureau forecasts and warnings refer to average wind speeds over a ten minute period. A storm warning is the most severe warning issued by the Bureau outside tropical latitudes.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Sydney Olympic Games
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 514)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games, upon notice, on 23 March 1999:

question.para: Does the Government propose to exempt the Sydney Olympics from a goods and services tax; if so, (a) why, (b) how would the exemption be administered, (c) who would determine what was and was not exempt, (d) would the exemption effectively result in Australian consumers subsidising the Sydney Olympics, (e) will she provide a list of exempt items and (f) would similar exemptions be available to other areas of sport and recreation and industry in general; if not, why not.

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss Jackie Kelly
talker.role: Sport and Tourism; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games (SOCOG), Sydney Paralympic Organising Committee (SPOC), overseas tourists and Olympic visitors such as athletes will pay the GST on the same basis as all other businesses and consumers.

The only exception will be the GST liability on Olympic and Paralympic ticket sales, which the Commonwealth will pay on SOCOG's and SPOC's behalf. The Commonwealth's offer to offset SOCOG's and SPOC's GST liabilities on tickets goes beyond the Prime Minister's commitment during the election campaign that tickets to the Games purchased before the introduction of A New Tax System would be GST-free. Under the Commonwealth offer, tickets sold before and after July 2000 will be treated in the same way.
Other areas of sport and recreation will be subject to the GST on the same basis as all other businesses and consumers.

talk.start.para: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 March 1999:

question.para: What percentage of unlisted companies paid the full rate of company tax in 1997-98.

talk.start.para: âThe Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: The prescribed rate of company tax for the 1997-98 year is 36 cents in the dollar. This rate applies whether companies are listed or unlisted. The exceptions to this rate are Life Companies, Registered Organisations, Pooled Development Funds and Credit Unions which pay at varying rates on different components of their incomes. For example, Life Companies pay at the rate of 15 cents in the dollar on the complying superannuation component of their income. For entities which fall into these categories the exact mix of their incomes will determine their average rate of tax.
The taxable income of a company and the prescribed company tax rate that will determine the amount of tax that a company will pay.

Concessions provided under the income tax legislation will affect a company's taxable income and the amount of tax it pays. These include accelerated depreciation deductions, research and development expenditure, inter-corporate dividend rebates and franking credits.

There are different methods of calculating a "tax rate" and each may provide different results, eg, calculation of tax on accounting profits rather than taxable income or using tax expense provision as against using actual tax paid. The Australian Taxation Office does not collect all of this type of statistical information.
